text: Love Love Love this place! If you're interested in climbing, this place is perfect. I finally took the plunge and became a member and couldn't be happier. The staff at VH is incredible! They always welcome you with a smile and are always willing to help. They are extremely encouraging too!The gym is great, the routes change often but not too often so that you can really harness your skills and challenge yourself. It's a super laid back feel and the sense of community is really special here. I've met so many wonderful people at this gym. They have a weight room that has all the basics you need and the upstairs has a slack line too.

I introduced rock climbing to my boyfriend about a year ago when I first saw Vertical Hold had a Groupon. We initially went to the Poway location, but now regularly go to the Old Town location. We started a couple's membership as we've been hooked on going back every weekend we can. SD/Old Town location definitely isn't as open as the Poway location, but has just as many great routes and staff. The Poway location has a bigger gym area, with 2 treadmills and a ping pong table. Vertical Hold staff members are always super friendly, whether they greet us or are helping out newcomers, they are always patient and willing to help. It seems like this location switches out routes on different walls every month or so, which helps keep routines from getting dry. There's always a challenging route that I want to complete before they switch it out, but also a great balance in easier routes for warm-ups and just being able to finish a climb. They have two auto-belays in case you come alone one day, and have several bouldering routes.Other climbers here are always nice, which is great to know there's a community here that is collaborative in giving pointers or tips for routes that may seem challenging to one person but isn't for another. I definitely recommend anyone to try rock climbing with their friends as it's a fun activity and gets your heart pumping - whether if it's from using all your muscle strength or the thrill of going to new heights you've never thought before!

I am beyond amazed that Vertical Hold let us bring our kids out to enjoy a day on the walls. We are a mentorship group with Urban Surf 4 Kids that serves foster youth and at-risk teens so when we were invited to bring our kids for a complimentary day was so moving. The confidence that is wrought from the struggle up a wall is extraordinary, just like our kids themselves. They begin the day thinking that they can't even go up the easiest of walls and end it racing up the more medium based challenging ones time and again to beat each others' times, pushing themselves each time up the wall.We serve our kids with Aloha and the giving bestowed upon our Hanai mentors and Hanai kids on this day is so graciously appreciated.Aloha to you and your amazing staff.Mahalo, US4K

My man & I hosted a little gathering for some of our friends. Luckily, the guy that helped my group was awesome! Shout out to Fran!  He made everything feel comfortable & provided great instructions! Everyone seemed to enjoy it. I wouldn't mind coming back if we want to do some belaying. Typically, I boulder at another gym. Great change up!

My friend and I bought a Groupon here.. and for $28/each.. we got a belay lesson, unlimited climbing, and gear for 1 month. The place is big and open. There are a variety of difficulty levels for climbs as well as climbs with ACT vs grigri methods. There is also plenty of bouldering. We took the full belay class-- Ben was our instructor and he was terrific as he was so patient and helpful. We quickly grasped the concept for figure 8 knots and the whole belay system. He had us climbing in no time.. the whole process took 45 minutes. And now we can join our other girlfriends who climb.. because we can prove to tie a figure 8 knot! Thanks Ben! We also saw kids there-- kids are able to climb but have to be at least 13 to belay. Anyways.. we will certainly be back. Looking forward to my next climb here.

We had an awesome experience at this place! The guy at the front was so nice and helpful. When we told him it was our first time at this place he welcomed us and helped us get the best deal. It was my second time ever rock climbing so instead of charging us for the beginner package he let us pay just for the day pass and gave us a quick refresh lesson with no charge! The whole staff is friendly and helpful. The gym is great! They have walls for beginners and more advance rock climbers. Everyone there seemed friendly and there was just a great vibe! We also had a very great time bouldering and using the other facilities -they have a weight lifting, stretching and a cardio area which is very convenient for a full work out. When we left, the guy offered us to come back later for a yoga lesson which was included in the day pass!

Came here today to experience rock climbing. One of my friends has become a rock climbing fan and we decided to see what it was all about. The entire process was simple and easy. If it's your first time then you use one of the iPads next to the desk and fill out a waiver. One of the staff members hands you a harness then some shoes. The staging area has cubbies for you to put in your belongings. Once you're ready, one of the staff members will teach you how to clip on, climb and belay. They'll stay to ensure everyone understands what they're doing and leave when everyone understands the basics.They have multiple routes with various difficulties. You can start off with 5.7 or just jump into 5.10. There are two rooms and there is a small upstairs area in each room. In the main room, there is a slack line you can try to walk on. They also have some yoga mats since I guess they also have yoga classes in the same building. In the other room is a huge area for buildering and upstairs are some weight lifting equipment. Their bathrooms are clean and they have a tiny locker room area. Not sure if intentional but the guy's bathroom had moisturizer which is super helpful when you dry your skin with chalk. They have tape and band-aids at the front if you need them. The environment seems super friendly. The staff is always ready to help you out. People are very respectful and mindful of others. Some people will actually cheer you on. I think this is super important if you're just starting out in anything. Finding a sport you like and a supportive community is always essential to anyone's fitness journey. I would definitely recommend Vertical Hold to anyone looking for a rock climbing gym or just to try rock climbing.Also...if you're unsure about trying rock climbing they do have packages available to help you ease into it. They also seem to have technique lessons if you want to further your skills. Lastly, if you are still on the fence about it, think back to when you were a child and you climbed, jumped and explored everything. Rock climbing is the grown up version of that.

This place is great. My boyfriend and I had a Groupon deal and wanted to try rock climbing for the first time. Their staff is pleasant and friendly, they are very welcoming to beginners and patient throughout the learning process. The gym itself always has available areas for climbing. There was never a time were I had to wait for anyone to climb. I highly recommend this place to beginners who are interested in climbing. Don't underestimate this gym, my arms and legs got an excellent workout. And it's so satisfying to see yourself progress in your climbing abilities.

The people running this place are super nice. I have been a member more for 6 months and yes it's really difficult to get into and there are other more expensive and maybe they have better locker rooms but this place is a real as it gets.Everyone is really friendly, offering advices and really great vibe. I def recommend you checking it out, they always have groupons promo and that's how I got hooked. Good luck.
First time here. Arianne and Melody were amazing! Would definitely come back to this gym for rock climbing. Everyone is super chill and good vibes! Check this place out :)

New to rock climbing or advance? Check this place out! Came here with family and my sister and nephew have never rocked climbed and they came it loving it! Staff is super friendly and helpful. If you are a student there is a discount. If you don't have the gear you can rent it all ( harness, shoes, chalk bag) for $20 all day pass. Reasonably price.  There are easy trails and harder ones you can even boulder. Make sure you have someone that can belay. Or can learn quick the staff shows you how to belay quickly as it does get busy.You get a nice work out in so added plus and children friendly. Would definitely recommend coming with a friend!

I've been coming here regularly for over a year now, and absolutely love this place!First off, my friend and I knew absolutely nothing about climbing when we first started coming in September 2017. Even so, as we went through the belay lesson (I don't remember now who took us through it, might've been Dorian), I never felt singled out or self-conscious about being a beginner, messing up the knots, etc. Staff were (and still are!) always very patient and accepting of all skill levels, and by the time we started going up the wall, we were at least confident that our knots would hold and we weren't going to die.After that, we started coming about once every 2-3 weeks for the next few months. Eventually we ended up getting our own gear instead of renting, but even when we were regularly using the gym's gear it never looked on the verge of dangerous--a little beat up, but sturdy. Staff are professional yet chill--it's clear they enjoy their work, are passionate about climbing, and aren't overly focused on making a buck. In fact, there were a few times when we were renting gear that the folks behind the desk would shrug and just tell us we could have it for free. (Don't take advantage of that, though--they deserve our money!) They also set new routes at a good pace, maybe every 1-2 months, which keeps everything new and refreshing.A year later, I'm climbing 5.10a's (and the occasional 5.10b on really good days), and my friend and I have the couple's membership. It's one of the best investments I make, IMO. We're not pros by any means, and I'm still pretty intimidated by the bouldering room, but whenever Wednesday rolls along and it's time to head to Vertical Hold after work, I'm always super pumped and excited.Only suggestion: a locker room would be great! Or at least a closing door with a lock to the women's bathroom area so there's a place for me to change from work clothes to gym clothes without taking up the only ladies' room in the place.

A true climbing gym.    On my visits to San Diego this is my choice of gyms.   The staff is incredible with sincere care for their climbers They have been around even when climbing wasn't a trend.   It's small, without all the bells and whistles of "new" gyms in San Diego It's well worth the visit.  A special shout to the "Dani".   Thank you for making my nieces feel welcome.

Had such an awesome time, the staff was so nice. It had been a while since I went rock climbing (only been once before years ago) so I needed to be refreshed on all the tips and techniques. Our instructor, Danielle, was very attentive and showed us how to belay and other safety tips that you need while climbing. I started out on the easier levels and found my self working my way up to the more challenging levels. What a great option for a work out, I felt so good afterwards, will definitely be returning soon!

This gym has very friendly staff and self-belay walls which is very convenient when you go on your own. However the walls are limited; not a lot of variety so if you have a membership it's hard to go over and over because you're doing the same thing. There is a very small gym with very outdated equipment so it's not very usable.

My sister's a member here and dragged me out for a full-body workout. While I didn't die as expected and am not the biggest climber around, I had a great time in the facilities. Service: as a first-timer, I had to sign a waiver but that was quick and easy. I hadn't learned how to belay before, but the staff was OK with my sister teaching me without imposing any additional fees or mandatory lessons (as I've heard other places do). It's also great that dogs are allowed inside, which makes the experience livelier and memorable. Size: adequate size, since we came off-hours around 730pm on a Friday night. My only complaint is the lacking amount of storage for personal belongings. Since there was no space, people were leaving bags on benches and floors. While no theft occurred, I'm wary when it does get busier.

If you're in the mood for some new hobbies or maybe you just want a new kind of workout, you cant go wrong with rock climbing! Vertical Hold makes it fairly easy to become a regular member, or if you just wanna try it out with some friends for a day, they've got decently priced $17 all-day passes as well!This place is formerly known as Solid Rock Gym. I've been here plenty of times before the new ownership in late 2016, and it seems like the set up is practically the same. Plenty of walls for harness climbs, bouldering, routes that change regularly. The 18+ boulder room is still there: bigger walls to practice harness-free climbs with mats all around. There is also a mini gym upstairs in the boulder room if you wanna warm up! Complete with weights, olympic rings, kettle bells, racks for squats/bench, bicep curls etc. There are even some pull-up looking platforms with different holds to practice strengthening your finger/forearm grip. Fans all around for a good cool down after climbs. I should also mention the gym upstairs seems cleaner and upgraded from prior ownership.The staff is super friendly, easy to help set you up with gear, climbing 101, yoga classes-- whatever you need to get you and your group started. A lot of people seem to be regulars with memberships, also making it a fun place to watch people with more experience. Not gonna lie, their membership deals aren't too bad either. I'm considering becoming more of a regular and this place has that nice local gym feel I'm looking for. Highly recommend if you're interested/new to rock climbing and wanna try it out for some good fun with friends. They've also got a 10% military discount, college discount on thursdays, and regular monthly events so plan accordingly! Climb on friends ~

I recently started rock climbing about a month ago and after the second week, I immediately got a membership. For those who are seeking a thrill and new ways to exercise, Vertical Hold is the place to go. First off, the staff is very welcoming. From the get go they provided excellent customer service and answered to what seemed like a million questions I had. You have the option of bouldering or top roping, meaning no harness vs harness. There are many different routes that range from beginner to pro, so dont feel left out if its your first time climbing. All in all, be ready for some blasted forearms and a sore back because rock climbing at vertical hold is addicting!

This place is great, it has a lot of well set walls, that are all really fun to climb. The staff is super friendly as well, it feels very welcoming here. It's also a great place to meet new people and hangout.

I visited with my brother, his girlfriend and my mom. Had such an amazing time with the amazingly friendly staff. The instructor, Shannon, was the sweetest and very patient with my mom as she was nervous about her first time climbing. My mom went from almost quitting to having a great time.Thank you again Shannon and Danielle for your patience and expertise!

Talk about a full body workout! I enjoy rock climbing and hope to get better at it. No better way to practice than at Vertical Hold. I guess I'm kind of biased since I've only gone rock climbing at this location even when it was Solid Rock Gym, but I enjoy this place. The staff are very friendly and helpful. They are willing to help you out if you have questions about anything!I always go with friends so we could belay each other but they have a boulders that you can try on your own. One day I will be able to do that once my arms don't decide to give up on me, but it's always worth a try. They have military and student discounts as well, so take advantage of that to save you some money!It does get busy at times especially at night, but for the times I've been there it wasn't too crowded to the point where there wasn't an open area. My suggestion is to stick to the same colors to guide you to the top especially if you're a beginner. But if you want to have a good time and get a workout, then Vertical Hold would be a great place to visit!
Staff is very polite and makes you feel comfortable like family.  My brother and I go here 3x a week.  Super fun and creative workout

The staff is awesome. They have to cater to a lot of kids with a limited staff and they do sooo well. I respect them for their patience. The place is smaller than Mesa Rim, but it was great and the paths were advanced. I loved the place and would go back for sure. Beginner's pay $30 to borrow equipment and the lessons. If you already know your stuff then it's $17 with borrowing the equipment. Not bad at all.

We had a great time!  We were here yesterday for a group event, Girl Scouts.  We had 20 kids and worked with Kenny.  He was friendly, fun and helpful.  All the girls had a great time and felt safe and adventurous.  I definitely recommend this place and Kenny.
Love this place! Awesome mix of climbing options. The staff is so nice. Always a great experience

I had a great time working out here today. The staff is friendly. There are plenty of courses and options for all ages and skill levels. I will be back as soon as my muscles aren't sore. If you are not sure about what you are doing they can and will give you a lesson to make sure everyone is safe!

I just wanted to say a special thank you to Matt for not only making me feel welcomed and comfortable here but also wanted. He thoroughly explained how I could get into the climbing community and how the beginner course here at vertical hold is held. Great information, polite and energetic attitude. Thanks man !

I've been here a few times since this location became a Vertical Hold gym and I really like it.  All the staff I've interacted with are very friendly their rentals are all good quality and well cared for.  They regularly switch up the bouldering room routes which keeps things interesting.  Definitely worth checking out if you're looking for a good indoor rock climbing gym.

The first time I went here was with my previous job. I actually had no idea it even existed. The place is very professional inside, well kept, very clean. The walls are always changing, there's a variety of level of difficulties and an additional room for the more experienced climbers. They even have a gym! It's a totally decent price to climb for a day, it is a lot cheaper if you have your own gear, but renting their gear for a day isn't breaking the bank. Going on your own or with just a couple friends is ideal, but they don't seem to handle large groups very well. Slightly understaffed and a little careless when the numbers increase. They don't help out too often for beginners or those just coming to have fun. A few staff members are really cool and they were helpful, but there's always one that can ruin the experience.

I LOVE this gym! I've been to others here in San Diego but this one takes the cake by far!! First off, yes they use gri gri belay devices; how awesome is that for newbies?!  I feel confident taking inexperienced climbers there, and teaching them the ropes. With so many routes to choose from, you'll never be bored. The ratings are a little off sometimes, but I'm also a shortie, so that probably has more to do with it than anything. Let's talk Boulder room: WOW! Incredible. Always on point with the routes, making it fun, and the traverse is rad too. I love how I can count on the routes to be changed frequently and you can follow solid rock on IG to see when routes are changing. You can utilize the natural features of the walls on some routes which is awesome. Customer service?? Yes!!  I have never once been treated poorly and the vibe in this place is super chill. If you're looking for a fun small gym with a non-corporate feel, solid rock is your place!!!

So much fun here. Helps me over come my fear of heights. It's a great workout too. I've been here 3-4 times with my company's adventure club. I feel like a badass when I make it to the top! Yay go me!
Super fun place to learn how to climb. You need to go with someone else to do the activity. Live the workshops wish there were more.

The employees at Vertical Hold are what make this place a hidden gem.  The first time my girlfriend and I came we brought our own gear but my girlfriend had a brand-new pair of shoes that turned out to be a little too small and painful halfway through our visit.  The guy at the front desk let us borrow a pair and when I tried to pay him for the shoe rental he refused my money, saying "we've all been there."  The routes are fun and they have some nice routes under the auto-belay if you feel like climbing alone.  I'll definitely be returning.

Before I started coming here, I couldn't climb a set of stairs. I was forever plagued of living in single story buildings. After 2 years of coming every day I'm sending 5.15s and am living out of a van. Shout-out to the front desk staff Dani and Matt

Awesome rock climbing gym.  You can climb ropes, rappel or boulder.  It's a pretty open gym so you can do whatever you want.  Once you get into the gym be sure to sign your waiver and select the package you want.  Best deal is to go with an unlimited monthly pass.  Be sure to bring your own rock climbing shoes and chalk so you don't have to use the gyms stuff.  You will have a blast!  Be ready to sweat!!!  Enjoy!!

I've been going to this gym for over ten years now, since I was a child having birthday parties here with friends. I've always loved the fun atmosphere, reasonable pricing, and of course, the very friendly and helpful staff. The variety of "skill-level" options is great - being a simple hobby climber and not seriously dedicated to reaching the highest degree, and it's a great way to have fun while working out your upper-body. I recommend this gym and will continue going as long as it's still open!

Thank you Josh for the amazing customer service! I have never been rock climbing and called to know what to bring and prepare for. He was so patient and kind on the phone and then even more when we arrived. He was informative to myself and two nieces and definitely a patient man that seemed to love his job. Will be back for sure!!
Really fun activity and the instructor did a great job. There are many different routes to try and I can't wait to try some more difficult walls!

This place is legit. It Has so much character and the routes are awesome. Challenging and tricky! They have some wise people setting up the routes and it's fun as hell! Not a corporate feel at all. People are chill and the atmosphere is great. My 2nd home :)! Thanks vertical hold! Shout out to Shannon! Thanks for making everyone feel like they belong!

Came here a couple of weeks ago with friends. It was my first time indoor rock climbing and loved the experience, but man do I have respect for people who do this for fun! It's definitely hard work, but I can see why people get obsessed. The place is clean, staff is friendly and the prices are fair.

Me and my friends try out a new activity each week and tried rock climbing yesterday. It was so much fun!!! Parking here was easy as they have a parking lot right outside. Our instructor Christina was so cool and chill and super funny!!! She made our whole entire experience. Def with a try!! PS students get a good rate of $10!!!!

Definitely not the most ideal climbing gym for those who want to top rope. But for the boulderers out there, a pretty nice spot.Pros: decent amount of space to boulder both near the top rope area and in its own room. Pretty nice alcove for lead climbers. Good for young birthday parties, groups, first timers. Friendly staff who are willing to.. literally.. show you the ropes ;)Cons: for the top ropers, although an OK place to learn if you've never done it before, the routes are kind of few and far between. The jump from white (easy) to 10.8s (the next lowest rating I could find) was a bit steep in my personal opinion. Also, the ropes and grigris seem  worn and old. When you descend, it's a cumbersome process for both climber and belayer because the ropes don't slide nicely through. You'll likely have to manually feed the rope into the grigri to speed it up (I'm about 110 lbs and my weight wasn't enough to lower me, so the manually feeding was a must haha). I prefer Mesa Rim myself, but I wanted to at least recognize this place for being kid-friendly and a good start for beginners.

The facilities here are a little bit older (not walltopia walls, pebbles rather than mats) but the staff make it a really great experience! Especially Alana who went above and beyond to make sure we had a great first experience here. The bouldering routes can be a bit more challenging for beginners but the belay walls are really great. We had an excellent time and Alana really made sure of that!!
Thanks for the great Welcom n awesome guudance for my lil strong RockStar baby girl... Dorian n Dani were a great help today- Cheers!

It was very clean and fun.  All staff was super nice and helpful, except the guy who said he couldn't wait until winter break was over. I was there with my 2 boys and I didn't appreciate the comment. But everyone else was cool.

Good value for the price. I do prefer Mesa Rim because I love top roping without the auto-lock belay. But if you want a good work out and don't wanna spend too much, this place will suffice. I give solid rock 3.5 stars, I rounded up. :)

A good place for beginners, especially because the belaying device (grigri) is already set for you so all you have to do is lock yourself in. The staff is pretty chill and they do military discounts on some days, you'll have to check. There are big mats you can move around for bouldering. I suggest getting your own pair of shoes if you're going more than once or bring your own thin socks to wear the shoes bc they are designed to be tight and can make your feet sweat like crazy.

Great prices for all day fun. This is somewhat perfect for a first date if he or she is athletic or is simply not afraid of heightsl. As for me I'm as scared as scary gets when i comes to high places and looking down. They sometime tell me to not look down and I do, but when they don't say anything I find myself paying more attention to whats at stake then whats below. Solid Rock was a fun time and I would love to go again and again. There are different levels from beginners to flat out one-handed spidermen. No worries the staff is super friendly and will assit you in every way. Open parking is just in front of the establishment. See you there soon...

First time rock climbing and came here with some friends. The staff seemed scatter brained and seemed like they didn't really care or want to be there, which I understand since it's probably just some crappy part time job. It was pretty expensive, especially renting rock climbing shoes. Turned out to be around $25.The rock walls were good, it appeared like there wasn't many walls for people who wanted just basic walls and nothing crazy, but I think there actually was a decent amount. Lots of kids, and kids birthday parties so it will be loud and obnoxious, including other people who are also just there as well. There were a few times where you just have to wait for people to finish climbing.I probably won't be back. It was exhausting and fun, but nothing crazy or special. Also expensive to just wear yourself out.

The employees here are fantastic. FYI: They recently (in Dec. '16) changed their name from Solid Rock to "Vertical Hold." The staff really is amazing. Went yesterday and was helped by Melody. She was so so so nice and really understanding despite the fact I had never rock climbed before. Best part is they let you rock climb in your own shoes (so if you're a noob and cheap, you don't have to spend $5 on shoes.) All in all, great experience.

The routes SUCK here. That being said, I'm not a veteran climber by any means, but could get up easier routes (5.9 and low 5.10) with ease at all the other rock climbing gyms I've been to (I was with Touchstone in the Bay Area). Here though... I got up half a 5.8. No exaggeration! There's no safety training at all when you first come in, and honestly, who the hell decided to have those little pebble/rocks as the floor? Walking around in my climbing shoes sucked a lot, and then there's the fact that I just felt like I was going to plunge down to my death for sure or at least break a ton/ankle if I tried to jump down. Heading to Mesa Rim from now on and forever. I don't think I'm hardxcore enough for Solid Rock.

First experience actually climbing and belaying without the help of an experienced person. The front desk team was so awesome and helpful to get us geared up and started and gave a brief and informative instruction on how to climb and belay each other with their gear.Tommy was first to help us and was awesome so helpful, and John have us out little lesson.The gym overall very clean and the vibes were amazing in there. Really good, chill music that really set the atmosphere. Overall the experience here was just awesome, really great people just hanging and having an awesome time.

For a first time climber, such as myself, it was a simple introduction to rock climbing. The staff was helpful and gave me a quick lesson in belaying, however that's about the only solid thing I can say about this gym. The walls themselves were in disarray and the way the paths were labeled made it hard to tell which rock went to which path at times. Also, the difficulty jump from the beginner paths to the next level (5.8) was quite the leap. It made it frustrating to go from a path that I could climb with my eyes closed to one where I couldn't even figure out how to get to the next rock. Granted some of this is due to me being a beginner, but I noticed others around me struggling with the same ordeal.

To quote John Cougar Mellencamp, "It hurts so good..."We came out to Solid Rock Gym as part of our friend's all-day bachelor party event this past Saturday.  This place was packed with kids; apparently, the gym is a really popular place for kids' parties (and with the number of rugrats climbing the walls like ninjas - some of them even blindfolded(!) - I can see why).  As for our group, most of us were climbing novices, and the only direction we were given was, "Guide with your hands, and push with your legs."  Nothing in terms of climbing safety - although they did point out what the tape on the walls was for.  Once my group got the hang of it, we all got our inner Ninja Warrior on, even if one wall managed to break us in the end.  Bloody #12... we will conquer you one day!The facilities themselves are pretty nice, though I wonder how often the handholds/footholds are cleaned (at many a point, I felt my hands slipping off a grip I had grasped solidly a moment prior).  There's also a bit of a tightrope area here, which all of us each had a go on... only to fall off after going at least a foot's distance.  One caveat - parking really is at a premium here; I found myself parking a couple of blocks away.Still, we had a great time here... even if our shoulders hurt and our fingers felt tender afterwards!

I have a membership here and I absolutely love it. Climb here all the time and the employees are cool. The rocks are never loose and the the routes are changed often so you never get bored with your membership. Oh and I absolutely love the fact they have a crack tower with 4 different cracks. All around I would say this place is pretty solid.
Good, affordable, and friendly place to climb.$10, for a day, for military and college students right now.I came here just to try rock climbing and it was a fun experience.

I've been climbing with a friend for a couple months. We bought climbing gear at REI and used our receipts yesterday for the free day pass at Vertical Hold on Hancock St. For one day, it was fine. It's old and a little rough. It was also empty, on a Tuesday. Almost all of the ropes have grigris tied into them with fairly ugly zip-tied knots, so you can't use an ATC except on a few routes. I think the grigris should be optional and everyone should be trained in how to use an ATC. The ropes on the grigris are completely stretched out and stiff. Crash protection is very limited - drag a pad to where you want to climb, or understand that if something happens and you hit the deck, it's going to be rocks. Personally I'll stick with Mesa Rim. It's cleaner, more professional, safer (the entire climbing floor is padded, bouldering section is double thickness) and has more amenities. But if you're on a budget or like the atmosphere better, VH is good.

This is such an amazing alternative to the different trails and work out methods I'm accustomed to and it's a terrific group activity to do with the fams. The only disadvantage to it is that when you do go with your family (especially with my cousins) you end up hurting more after because of all the laughter generated by our stupidity. Fellow rock climbers, we apologize whole-heartedly for our rambunctious ways.What I love most about the gym is that there are so many scenarios for your to put yourself through. If you're a beginner, they've got a wall for you. If you're Spiderman, they've got a wall for you too. And if your someone like me who's down for a challenge but not enough to cling horizontally for dear life, then they've got you covered. For $21 bucks, you're laced with a harness and a whole world to explore... until 9:00 on Saturdays. The staff is friendly and the place is generally clean. Location-wise, it can be slightly hard to find because you might catch yourself heading back onto the 5 South if you're not careful. But I can tell you that it's a great work out and you'll definitely wake up with your upper body pleading for more rest.

Newbie alert! I went with a group of friends this weekend and got a great upper body workout. I had no idea what to expect like, do I need a helmet? (no) will my delicate hands get caluses? (yes, small, but they're there!) do I trust my friends enough to make sure I won't fall to the ground? (yes, great trust building activity ;)) will I break a nail? (no, chip free is the way to be)After figuring out how to put on the harness, the guy at the front dest gave us a quick run through on climbing safety and belaying basics (this alone was a workout). There are color coded tapes on each rock along the walls for you to follow certain routes ranging from easy to difficult. We were able to do most of the rope walls for the 2 hours we were there. This is a great place for beginners, there's a small area in the middle of the gym for rock climbing without ropes.$23 for 1 day pass, harness, and shoes. I wore gym clothes and some Nikes but opted for the shoe rental. I recommend renting the shoes since they were much lighter and slimmer to wedge onto the rocks.

Solid rock rules. All of the staff do a GREAT job of making you feel welcome and comfortable. I've been a member for a little bit now and it's super addicting and challenging. When I first started going I was pretty intimidated... but thankfully everyone who climbs there and the staff crush the pretentious vibes that I have gotten at other climbing gyms. I appreciate the multiple locations and I almost gave a four star because I will all of them had showers but oh well, these guys deserve the 5 stars!!chalk up suckers!

Great place to get introduced to indoor rock climbing. It's small but perfect for someone who just wants to check it out! The people who work there are friendly and very helpful. It's been quite sometime since I've been there because I moved, but I remember Karen was super nice & helpful with answering all our questions. This place doesn't have the fancy look or feel of other rock climbing gyms, but it's great for what it is. Looking for something different to incorporate into your week? Then give this place a go... you'll either say ya or nay when you're through, then you can give your own review :)

It seems like the owner doesn't give a crap about this place.  Maybe I'm just spoiled by going to Vertical Hold a bunch of times before trying Solid Rock.Tags marking routes are falling off all over the place (or are all the way off).  Tags are just pieces of tape.  Why not use something that is sturdier and looks better?  Maybe it's just me, but the lack of caring about the way the place looks made me wary about how much anyone cared about anything else - like safety.When you sign in, they don't give you any information or make you sign a waiver.  Then, there are some signs in other places in the gym that say by signing in, you are agreeing to whatever is on these signs.  I guess they think that is a waiver?  Don't give any safety information and then say by signing a paper you agreed to something you probably never saw (a sign in another location)?  Not sure if that would hold water if someone got hurt here, but I'll leave that to the people getting paid to answer those legal questions.No belay training required to belay others, as other reviewers have stated.  Scary.The bathroom was a mess, trash can was completely over-filled and had overflowed onto a good portion of the floor.I'm sure it is really hard to clean the chalk (and sweat, and other stuff) from the rocks (the entire floor is rocks - you have to drag crash pads around for protection), so my allergies were going nuts from all the chalk dust.  I also saw a mouse, so there's probably some other stuff in those rocks too.I would love to love this place and give them my money because it is so close, but it seems so unprofessional that I would not go back.  It just made me uncomfortable.

Went last night with a friend.  We had a blasted.  1st timers.  The staff was extremely accommodating.  Plenty of walls to climb.  We will definitely be back.  Great time, great place. Yes I recommend it.

This is a great place to go climbing. I'm not from San Diego and I was staying with friends for a week and wanted to do some climbing while in town. This place has a lot of bouldering, 2 rooms in fact, and also has belay. It's great for all levels of climbers. Friendly atmosphere and good price. Would definitely come back if I'm ever in town. I gave 4 stars because I'm used to massive climbing gyms in San Francisco, so this felt small to me but it is still a good size with lots of options. Happy climbing!

This was a pretty cool climbing gym with a lot of options for both top rope and bouldering. I loved that they had the slack line up stairs, I used it as an intermission for my hands when I was getting tired. In my opinion though, their bouldering routes are a little sloppy.

Fun, kinda small, but really fun! Me and my boyfriend came here for both our first times the other night and the guy at the front taught us how to do everything. It started to get busier and we only lasted an hour and then our hands hurt (get the chalk!) but we both loved it and will be returning!

We had our daughters 7th Birthday Party here with about 15 kids and it was great. The children really loved it, the parents had fun, and Rick our instructor was great. The upstairs party room was wonderful as well. It was so easy as far as kids birthday parities go! Only down side was it did start to get crowded during the last hour of the party which made it a little harder to get the kids up on the easier routes. But it all worked out and everyone had fun!

Randomly decided I wanted to take up rock climbing, so I convinced some friends to come with me. It's $20 on the weekday to climb and rent equipment, total, which I think is super affordable. We all enjoyed it, so we jumped in on a 6 mo. membership. If you only climb twice a month (which is easy to do and you'll likely climb more), the membership pays for itself, so it's definitely worth considering. Also, they have auto-locking belay devices, so it's essentially fool-proof. I'm sure for liability reasons on their part, but I appreciate it.
A really good variety of skill level sets. The employees are awesome. They also have specials on Fridays for military!

By far the best rock climbing gym in San Diego. Very welcoming to new members and new climbers! They foster a safe but fun environment for learners and expert climbers. The bouldering is fun and diverse, and the climbing walls offer a range of skill levels. The best part about this gym is the atmosphere and community--fun, friendly, and safe!

My daughter had her birthday party at Solid Rock today, and to quote her "Best. Birthday. Ever." It was a great space, the instructor was awesome, and the kids had a blast. We did the party right when it opened, before it was too busy, and it was perfect. Loved the fact that there were bouldering walls, lots of different climbing options, and plenty for all the kids to do.We'll be back for more climbing without the whole party.Thanks to the entire staff at Solid Rock for a great day!

Was staying in downtown and paid a visit to Solid Rock. Here's the skinny:It's an older gym so don't expect it to be sparkling clean. It serves the local climbing community and kids parties at quite a clip.Routes were ok as I have climbed better and worse. If you are really into climbing indoors, its worth the drive to go check out Mesa Rim further north.

I enjoyed coming here, the staff is very friendly and helpful. However the cost for a day is ridiculous. I believe they should do hourly rates, because lets face it how many people are going to climb all day? It is a little run down. The three stars are for not so great parking and the cost for a day pass. I might only come here once a year or so, but would look for a cheaper day pass place.

This is a little painful to write but I have to. The climbers at Solid Rock are a great crowd and I really like the vibe there. I give them a 5 star review for sure and I even like the pebbles over the pads, plus the convenient location of the gym is just hard to beat.Unfortunately, the administrative style of the gym has disappointed me beyond belief. They are completely inflexible and do not understand the needs of their paying customers. They need a doctor's note even for a minor injury (a single visit to the doctor can easily cost $100!) in order to pause membership and in order to cancel membership it absolutely must be done by the 25th of each month, otherwise they charge you FULL for the next month. I tried cancelling it the following day and there was just no reasoning with them. We had every intention of coming back to this gym (we had to pause/cancel our membership for a few months) but now we're probably going to go to Vertical Hold instead. It's incredible to see how I couldn't possibly imagine changing gyms when I first wrote my review. The owners of this gym should focus much more on customer service in order to keep your paying customers happy. Otherwise you'll lose them just like you've lost us, we're moving our three memberships elsewhere.

I've been going to SR for about a year and love the place.  I've been to all the other gyms in town and dig solid rock the most.  The crew they have are super friendly, cool people.  Ben, Josiah and Tommy make the place.  Rad vibe and cool community of people.  They've got a nice little lead dome and they always have a slack line up.  Highly recommend it.

Etiquette of climbing participants could be better. Staff is super friendly and informative. Overall, as a climbing gym, the routes are fun & the terrain is perfect to train on. Not many gyms top out their boulders with true mantles.

This is a great alternative to your average gym sesh! For nearly $20 or so, you have rentals & climbing to try! Don't worry if you're a newbie because their trained staff will ensure you understand the terminology and how it works before you venture out on your own. Grab a couple friends and check this place out for some gnarly fun. It's always good to try new things :)

Having never experienced any of San Diego's rock climbing gyms, I set out to try Solid Rock in Old Town.  What a great workout for your core, legs and mind.  The gym was a little busy as there was a French school doing a group outing on site but my friend and I had no problem finding our own area.  They have some challenging routes and decent bouldering area as well.  The thing I like about the gym though was the option to try slacklining as well.

Great indoor climbing gym for any level of experience! Pretty cheap too! They show you what to do and they are constantly switching up the courses so it's never the same. They also have a bouldering room for those who love to Boulder! You can rent your gear from here too!

Very disappointed. I'm trying to cancel my membership over the phone and the staff won't let me. I moved so trying to get over there is extremely inconvenient. That being said the routes aren't that great. They rarely switch it up and the walls are crowded. The place isn't any sort of clean and it's just a lousy experience. Just skip this place and go to Mesa rim or a nicer gym because this place will try and milk you for every penny.

We had our daughter Sophie's 10th birthday party at this Solid Rock today and it was a wonderful experience. The staff was great the kids had a fantastic time and it was was a lot of fun for the kids and the adults. Thank you to the staff for taking the time to instruct the kids and helping them with the equipment, climbing, and tether line fun.

Worst gym around.  Shocked it has such good reviews....maybe its because they removed my last one and probably countless other 1-star ratings.  1. No music and awkward atmosphere2. Terrible and boring routes and inaccurate ratings3. Grimy, unclean holds4. Way too few crash pads5. Rude, unhelpful staff

Maybe I just got spoiled by nicer gyms at better prices but, I was really disappointed with this place for the price. The rock wall pegs just didn't seem like they were setup well and instead of mats or floor they have rocks on the ground that made the whole place dusty.

Solid fun experience, been here before. Overall good fun if you bring a bunch of friends.  I would give it a 5 star but the blonde girl that works on Tuesday afternoons is rude and has an attitude. Beside that costumer service is great !

Good variety of climbing surfaces, from crack climbing to bouldering the selection of what you want to climb and how hard you want it to be is all there. The staff are very responsive to any questions new climbers may have as well as very willing to let experienced climbers do their thing. The location is spacious and well suited for larger parties. If you are a climber or are going to get back into the sport, this gym is a great place to do it.

I just had a birthday party for my daughter (turning 7) at this gym. They have an area upstairs where you can bring your own food, drinks, and party decorations. All the parents who came with their children enjoyed watching their kids climb and belaying them. This gym was ideal for introducing the parents and children to a new, challenging sport. Many of the parents told me they had a great time. They had reasonable group rates and only charged for the kids that actually climbed. The staff (Christian, Ben, and Tatum) were extremely helpful and friendly. I had a very positive experience with this gym, and I would recommend parents consider this venue for birthday parties and group events.

This is the first time I've reviewed any service on yelp, but our experience at solid rock was so poor, that I felt the need to warn actual rock climbers who might want to check this place out.My fiance and I love trying new indoor rock gyms when we travel, and have been to quite a few. This place is by far the worst.Safety last. This gym does not require that you pass a belay test or take any type of instructional class in order to climb.  They have pre tied first gen Gri-Gris on bowlines with zip ties keeping the knots in place.  The locking biners and other hardware are ancient and many sides or corners of the biners were very sharp to the point that I was afraid they would cut either my harness strong points or the rope. The ropes have obviously never been replaced since their inauguration and were so worn and flat that they would often times not feed through the belay device. The routes clearly do not get reset and so the holds never get cleaned or replaced causing them to be very slippery.  A hold spun on me while climbing and when we notified the staff member she blankly stated, "yeah, doesn't that make the route so much harder," as if that were a good thing.  She did not offer to fix the hold and we questioned whether or not the gym even owned an allen wrench.  If you belong to this gym please for the love of god get an experienced guide or mentor to teach you... basically everything over again before attempting to climb outdoors.  The guy at the front desk saw that I was belaying without ever taking my break hand off of the rope (I'm used to an ATC) and told me that since I was using a Gri-Gri I did not need to worry about keeping my break hand on the rope.  WOW!!!  Also, the two guys that were lead climbing were jumping around like apes and almost swung into me twice while lowering. NO, you do not need to or ever should clip the anchors and then jump out and sideways as far as you can to look cool after completing a route.  If you do this outside the rock can and will cut your rope.In point, the gym was gross and clearly not maintained, the staff was obnoxious and not knowledgable, and safety is clearly not a concern.  Also, the routes are some of the least creative and un-intuitive (basically they make absolutely no sense) routes that I've ever climbed on.Don't climb here.

This place rocks! Went with a group of 8.  2 of us had never done it before and the other 6 were regulars going twice a week.  I was the newbie and was impressed by how many different course options there were and difficulty levels.  If you've never gone rock climbing - this gym would be a great place to start.  The people that work there are very knowledgeable and genuinely enjoy the sport.  The night we went there was a meet up group at the same time.  So lots of people with varying skill levels and the place never felt crowded or full.   Other rock climbers are also very friendly and courteous.  It was great to mix up the work out and focus on upper body strength and skill.

First off, many of these negative reviews are laughable. Seems like most folks are grossly uneducated on what Rock Climbing Gyms are like. Solid Rock offers more than 30 top roping routes, crack climbs, a phenomenal lead cave as well as exceptional bouldering. When novice climbers come in, or even those who have climbed before who just want a refresher, SRG gives FREE Belaying lessons. Why? Because safety IS priority there. The staff is incredibly knowledgeable and will answer any questions people have. Routes are reset every three months or so so that no one gets bored. Plus, you have time to nail those routes that shut you down a time or two. They also have an amazing kids climbing team. The coaches blow my mind with how encouraging and positive they are with these young kids. SRGs manager, Mike, is most definitely a no bull shit kind of guy, which is exactly what that place needs. In an environment where safety is essential, Mike does a fabulous job at keeping SRGs record of almost 20 years (which is the amount of time they have been established) of ZERO major accidents or injuries. They must be doing something right! I have three young kids and Mike has been incredibly patient with teaching them the rules of climbing and helping foster their skill. SRG has faithful and wonderful members and staff and I am incredibly grateful to have found them! Parking is not plentiful, but it is located in an industrial area... none of the businesses there have an abundance of parking, but there IS ample street parking. Don't cry about having to walk 1/8 of a block to get to the facility... you are going for a work out. Get over it. That is hardly a reason to give a negative review. Rock as a landing is actually what MANY rock climbing gyms use... when I jump down from a route I may have gotten shut down on when bouldering, I land in the rocks (only if I didn't have the crash pad near by... I usually set the crash pad further along my route for if I take a big fall). When doing so, the rock spread out to soften my landing. A mat would send a pretty impressive shock wave up my leg, and doing that repeatedly would surly result in an injury. Using the rocks allows for better distribution of the weight of impact, much like someone laying on a bed of nails. There is a scientific purpose, and clearly folks do not take the time to understand WHY things are done the way they are. Don't let someone's bitter review sway you from checking them out for yourself. Moral of the story: Solid Rock Gym Old Town will Rock your world. Pun intended.
This is the 2nd time I have brought my kids here and they are very good with them. They take their time to make sure they understand before they let them loose. Great atmosphere and great service!
Here as we speak wrapping up a 12th bday party. Can't recommend this place enough! Great place, great instructors (Ben), great price. We cannot wait to come back! THANK YOU SO MUCH!!!

The first rock gym I went to was in Monterey Bay. First off, who puts ROCKS as landing ground for this gym?? The other one I went had cut up tire pieces. Much safer and softer landing.I've taken a few people here for their first time experience so it did the job but the last time I went it smelled like feet which would make sense because of the people taking off their shoes and replacing it with the rock climbing shoes. This gym is bigger than the one I experienced but I wouldn't say better.The crew is quite apathetic. Shape up, Rock solid in Old Town!!
Great climbs! I want to go here again and this time actually try them all out. I only tried about 5 different climbs but they were harder than I thought.

Some of these reviews are comical and make me extremely angry. Most of these people are first time reviewers or perhaps think they know about rock climbing but clearly don't. To say Solid Rock never replaced ropes or routes is ignorant. I see them constantly working on setting routes and know they reset something at each of their locations every two months. The reason for any slippery or spinning holds is because of the amount of traffic coming through the doors. Anyone looking through reviews will notice how crowding is often mentioned. So what do you get when a gym is constantly busy and greasy hands are constantly climbing the holds, greasy holds all too soon. I climb here at least twice a week and get a crazy good work out and find the routes challenging and fun! The setters take time to perfect their work and tweak a route until it works. That said, they do grade a bit harder here than most softer gyms as they try to mimic the outdoors. There are easy routes but everything takes practice and I, at my start of rock climbing, felt discouraged. Come with an open mind and be positive please.

Been meaning to post this for months now, but it was never the right time for me.   And I do hate giving one star ratings...  My cousin and I decided to check it out.  I called ahead of time to make sure we were prepared.  I asked about appropriate clothing and shoes.  I also let them know that we would be needing an instructor as it was our very first time rock climbing.  After we arrived, I tried to inquire at the front desk to get started.  It took a while to get anyone which was weird because there seemed to be a lot of staff coming in and  out of the door behind the counter and walking around.  One person told me he would get someone to help and 15 minutes later I had to ask someone else for help.  :(  "Ok...  They're busy.  I understand.  It's Saturday."  Finally we get some help and I start small talk.  Just wanted them to remind him that we were beginners again because I was nervous!  LOL  We finally get our harnesses and the guy walks away (to God knows where).  Me and my cousin are left to figure out the harnesses.  Guy gets back and takes us to an area and  tells us that the area he has taken us to is not really for beginners but didn't have a choice as there was a birthday party taking place so that area wasn't available.  THAT should have been a red flag, I know. (-_-)  The instructor didn't explain ANYTHING!  He just told me to hold the end of the rope and told her to start climbing!  LOL He was still standing with us but instead of watching my cousin climb or instructing me as she was climbing he was looking everywhere else.  She got about 4ft up and dropped, landed incorrectly and ended up injuring herself.  This guy freaked out.  He had no idea what to do.  These guys are NOT  well equipped for injuries/emergencies which surprised me.  I thought these guys would have at least known First Aid.  Luckily I'm a nurse.  But this really has me concerned. I asked about a refund and the manager informed me they don't give refunds and proceeded to offer me vouchers that didn't expire to come back in the future!  Ok.  At that point I wanted to slap someone. LOL  Really?!  You really think we're coming back?!  We ended up contacting the owner who was apparently away on vacation at that time and he has happily refunded us and sent us a lengthy apology letter.  However I didn't care.  All I want is for him to teach their employees how to properly handle emergency situations and work on their severe lack of management & professionalism.

My first experience rock climbing.  Brought the kids since one of them had just finished rock climbing camp last week.  I have nothing to compare it to, but the overall experience was pretty great.1.  Friendly and knowledgeable staff - Tommy spent time to teach us first-timers the basics.  The instructions were simple and easy to follow.  Throughout the morning I saw Josiah repeat them to incoming climbers.  2.  Surprisingly kid-friendly for my toddler who tried "bouldering" a little and at one point even put a harness on.3.  Affordable and accessible.  I thought the set up was fine, with many different course options.  I would seriously consider doing a birthday party here for my kids, a Happy Hour, or Girl's Night Out.Thanks to Melissa, Tommy and Josiah for making my initial experience a positive one!

So me and my gf decided we were gonna try indoor rock climbing looked it up and found this place. First off I'm a picky guy and and hard to please but this place was amazing the staff very welcoming specially the guy with the long hair
Great place to climb some rocks. The staff was awesome and helpful. If you're up for a challenge you'll find it here.

Worst climbing ever. Parking and entry make you question going in to begin with. Staff was rude and not helpful at all; didn't even ask if we've climbed before or know how to use the equipment. Rocks you have to walk on ruin your shoes, ratings are totally wrong, ropes are too short, staff sat behind the desk on their phones instead of keeping an eye on customers. Will never come back, mesa rim is 1000% better.
First time here, employess were verey friendly an helpful for beginners. Im hooked ill be coming here more often with my friends!

Ok place to climb. Found a lot of lines that seemed like they had missing feet holds, which inadvertently turns a V0 into a V2 and is not the kind of situation you want to be in as an inexperienced climber 12' off the ground. My favorite thing about this place is the boulder/gym room, but only because you can plug your own music in their stereo and giant (speaker).

Came here with a group of friends for a birthday party during the week. I was pretty surprised how full the gym was on a Thursday evening. Regardless, there was someone right at the front waiting to set us up with harnesses and shoes, I recommend wearing "gym" attire for girls as it can get pretty sweaty! The staff was friendly enough and only took us about 10 mins to go over the rules and saftety procedures. Got in a good workout while kickin it with friends.There isn't any lockers so I'd recommend traveling light. Don't forget to bring some water and socks for your shoes! Overall it was a really fun time!

This is definitely a situation where I'm glad I didn't get the opportunity to read reviews before my visit...I suppose for the more experienced rock climbers - this isnt the #1 choice?  I dunno, it was my first time ever rock climbing so this review is probably more helpful for someone in my shoes.  For an all-day weekend pass + rental gear and shoes, it's $21.  I thought that is pretty fair for an out-of-the-norm weekend activity.  If you get there before noon, the place isn't too crowded.  I found around the time we took off (1:30) it had about tripled in the amount of people.The experience as a whole was very enjoyable.  We got started right away and after putting our harnesses on, the staff member gave us the low down on how to operate the ropes and be safe.  I thought he explained everything easily and made me feel comfortable and safe as a first timer.  We each took turns in the different roles with his assistance and once we felt good about what we were doing we were sent off to climb around at our leisure.I thought the variety of terrain was good and their system of colored tape to distinguish the experience level of the routes was very effective.Great activity for a couple, a few friends, and probably even a group of people.  I wouldn't call this a good date with a new person given the oh-so-attractive crouch-factor.  I gotta say, here's a funny opportunity to see guys "lay it all out for you."  I was thoroughly amused at what the harasses does for the males :)I made the mistake of wearing shorts...probably not the smartest idea with the angle people are seeing you from below and the whole harness thing.  Make sure to wear longer shorts (like knee level) or khakis...something like that.  I saw people wearing straight up jeans but that doesn't seem very smart to me.Overall, cool place to try out if you've never done it before.  The staff is friendly and knowledgeable, you feel very safe, and you are entertained for as long as your hands and arms can hold out.I'm typing with some rather awesome blisters on my hands right now!
One of the best indoor rock gyms my husband and I have been too. great deals for military families. great place for first timers or experienced climbers!

In a nut shell: -Good gym to get your climb on. I'm more of a fan of the bouldering but the rope routes are decent too. A bit lacking but it has a worn-in, homey feel. -Don't hesitate to try it out. Pros: -For me, close to home. You can even take the trolley if you so choose. -Very challenging lead climbing cave -Pretty good bouldering area, although it gets crowded quickly (on a side note, some guy wanted to fight me because I was in his way... even though I was there first). -Difficulty levels from very easy, to extremely hard so there is something for everyone. Cons: -Parking can be a pain in the ass especially at night when I see the most people there. -There are always a lot of kids here. I have no problem with them but they sometimes get in the way and are loud. -The floor is rocks. I prefer foam for indoor places. That's just me. -The walls are tall, but not tall enough for me. Little details: -Staff is friendly but I got the impression that they thought they were better than me the first time I went. Every other time I just ignored it. -They have some decent clinics but mine got rescheduled 2 times before I actually went. -They have a small gym area above the main entrance/office. -Slack line, pegboard, and crack wall can be found in the bouldering area which is cool because there aren't kids running around everywhere (kids are not allowed in the bouldering area without an adult, if I remember correctly).Overall: -Check it out, I doubt you will regret it unless you are super nit picky and have ultra-high standards. -Fun if you want a good workout or just want to monkey around.-Good practice before you hit the real stuff.-I will return but I found a place that works better for me.

The team was amazing! There was a while group of kids in and they did such an awesome job. They worked really hard! I was super impressed. They were also witty and fun, made the entire experience unforgettable. Thanks guys!

2012 was my boyfriend's and my Year of Debauchery. We traveled near and far and got nothing short of OBLITERATED in every corner of the contiguous US of A. It was awesome, but spending most of the year either drunk or hungover took its toll on my body and probably my mind. It just took me 30 seconds to figure out if it's pronounced "con-TIH-guous" or "con-ti-GYOO-us." My brain no worky so good and six. So we decided that 2013 should be the Year of ADVENTURE. After a soul-clearing trip to Yosemite we vowed to try something cool and new and exciting at least once a month, preferably something that would benefit our life-expectancy instead of slashing it nearly in half. This month, we wanted to try out a rock climbing gym because nothing says ADVENTURE like shuffling across plastic rocks indoors.I decided on SRG Middletown despite the multiple scathing reviews for two reasons: proximity and price. It's pretty close to us, and for our first time (and because we figured we'd only last like, twelve minutes before collapsing in a sweaty heap on the floor [that's what she said]), the $23 initial price (as opposed to Vertical Hold's $31 and Mesa Rim's $30) seemed the best use of our money. In retrospect, we probably should have dropped the extra dough for a legit lesson in belaying and knot-tying at one of the other gyms, because the SRG "belay lesson" was pretty bare bones. I can kind of understand people feeling like the safety was lacking (especially if they're "heights averse"), but if you pay attention and use common sense there really shouldn't be an issue. I do wish they'd given us a tour or explained the numbers and color rating system and whatnot, but I'm sure if we'd asked they'd have gladly helped.As for the "GROSS" shoes everyone speaks of, I personally did not notice any particular stench. Then again, I don't stick my nose in RENTAL ROCK CLIMBING SHOES TO CHECK FOR CLEANLINESS BECAUSE I AM NOT DISGUSTING. The climbing itself was a blast - we showed up early (about 9:45) so even for a Saturday we had no trouble getting to climb as many routes as we wanted - although a little girl's birthday party started on our way out... I can't IMAGINE how the place looked then. The Dude enjoyed bouldering more than the top rope climbing, so we spent some time in that room too. Within about an hour and a half, my hands were too tender to continue, although I wished I could have kept going all day! That shit it FUN, yo. I can definitely see myself getting into climbing once I develop some callouses on these frail little flower petal fingers. I'm sure we'll eventually hit up some of the other climbing gyms in the area, and maybe then we'll understand the hate goin' on. For now, though, Solid Rock is A-OK.

I've been here a few times & it was simply a new and fun way for me to get a workout in. It's doable for anyone whether you have no experience at all or are very experienced at rock climbing. It was $20 for the gear and you're allowed to climb for as long as you want. Memberships are also offered which would probably be cheaper if you plan on going often.
This place is awesome...  Nice location off the freeway...  Not too packed on a Saturday...  Got a great workout...  Will come here many more times...

I'm a climbing novice and this is my first indoor gym experience. I've been here twice now.My biggest concern here is safety. They pretty much gave us our harnesses and said "have at it", without belay instruction or anything. I had to rely on my friend to teach me how to properly belay, and he is fairly new to climbing also.It's ok for me since I'm new and I suck, but I've heard there are better gyms (Verticle Hold, Mesa Rim). I'll keep coming here to gain skill and experience then work my way up to the other gyms so I don't look like a total noob. I do like its proximity to where I live, I think its the closest climbing gym to Downtown.
Horrible website. Note user friendly at all. Does not even have prices posted!

This place is super fun! It's an excellent workout. I advise bringing a buddy because it's a lot more fun/productive when can communicate with a person you trust. There are a plenty of courses to take and they color code the difficulty level so you don't wind up climbing up a wall that you simply can't conquer. It's decently priced and they also have a month membership. If you plan on visiting regularly, I highly recommend buying a harness elsewhere, otherwise it's about $5 to rent one. I really wish I started a long time ago, I'd be a lot more fit by now! The walls encourage me to come back so I can finish what I started. It's great for people who like to challenge themselves, especially in the fitness department. Also, prior to going, I let the cashier know it's been years since I last climbed and he gladly sent someone to help instruct me and my partner. He gave us tips on belaying and climbing. I also used my regular gym shoes which turned out just fine, but I think if you rent their shoes, you'll have more success climbing because they may have a better grip. Check out the gym though, you'll get a good sweat and have fun! Missing 1 star for the small parking lot! But it's worth it!

Went here for the first time today and I love rock climbing now. Great upper body strength! But one thing I didn't like was that it was small and you find yourself doing the same ones over and over again. And the safety issue here should be more strict like at least having the workers stand around and watch the people belaying eachother instead of sitting behind the counter doing nothing.

Love this place! I got my membership in January and go as often as I can. Awesome boulder room and lead cave. Tommy, Ben, Josiah, and the rest of the solid rock staff are not only helpful, but also extremely welcoming and encouraging. From beginners to experts, it is a great community!

This is the third rock climbing gym that I have been to and I think it was my least favorite.  Instead of having mats on the ground to fall on, they have rocks and it seems to be a little bit more pricey than other gyms.  All in all it is not bad but it is not great I am no rock climbing expert but it was just okay.

I've been going to this gym regularly for almost 2 years now. I wouldn't say it's the best gym in town because it lacks some standard gym amenities, but they do have some great climbs. The staff are friendly and the regular climbers are cool too.I think it's good for first timers and from what I've seen they do a good job with kids parties. They usually have groups of kids coming through for summer camps and parties so the staff are all used to dealing with the kids. During summer and school holidays there are a lot of kids on the top-ropes but the boulder room and lead-cave are always kid free. What made me convert from the occasional day pass to an annual member is the 18+ boulder room. The overall shape, and even the texture, of the new boulder is fantastic. They are able to create some really great routes. I wish they had a padded floor rather than the rocks and crash pads though. Nothing more sketchy than trying a dynamic move with your heel hooked in a horizontal position 10 feet from a pile of rocks.I also agree with some previous posters that the ratings seem to be easier than they actually are. A 5.9 top-rope at Solid Rock is probably 5.10 at other gyms, I can see how that might bruise the ego of the visiting climbers but I like it. Whenever I go to another gym or outside I'm able to complete routes one rating higher than I can do at Solid Rock.They also have a free weight gym upstairs, but it rarely gets used during the day. For me, this is where they loose some points. I can see that it doesn't get used much during the day, and that's probably why the're not investing in it, but maybe it's not being used because it's so small and lacking some basic equipment like an elliptical or cycle. More than 3 people in the weight room and it's overcrowded. I'm sure 95% of the people that come in are only there for the climbing so it's understandable that they don't invest in it, but I'm in the other 5%. On the positive side, at least they *have* a weight room. They have several benches, full rack of dumbbells, plenty of barbell plates, rings, and finger boards.  I'd like to give 5 stars, but there are a few things that bug me:- Need to clean up the lockers, they are all covered in chalk dust. The bottom of the locker shelves are as dirty as the floor. - The weight room is also covered in chalk dust because that's where the finger boards and rings are. - Get at least one elliptical or cycle for some cardio. Just truck one down from the Poway gym!- Need to maintain the tape on the routes. Nothing makes a route more difficult than an unmarked hold. The top-rope routes are pretty well maintained but the boulder gets more and more difficult as the tape falls off.- It would be really nice if they went for a more traditional gym approach with the weight and locker rooms.Even with the few gripes I have, I'm happy with my membership here. I plan to have future birthday parties for my kids there when they get older and I will likely renew my membership as long as they continue to invest in new holds and keep that boulder room fresh.

I like this gym and it's the one I visit the most because it's closest to me. I would love to give this place 5 stars for being a climbing gym but I feel like it could be a lot better. At first I was really sad about how expensive this gym is... I guess the price is average (at least in SD) but I refuse to come here when I'm not apart of a long term membership because the per-visit cost would kill my wallet.My biggest complaint here is that the routes are poorly taken care of by staff. My favorite climbing style is bouldering and the boulder section is always missing tape from routes or is hanging on by it's last sticky bit of life and the employees don't fix it. The employee's tend to sit behind the counter even when there is more than one on the clock and I feel like they shouldn't. If even just once a day, they checked the tape and replaced ones that are needing to be replaced, this place would be at least a star better. It's almost like no one has any pride or ownership of this place. Even when I ask an employee where I'm missing tape, they might tell me what they think it was and they still wont care to fix it and if they made rounds just once a day, there would never be a lot of work to keep it maintained. it's frustrating! The ropes are old and they feel gross. I want them teach people how to belay and how to put a grigri on a rope properly or just anything that will teach someone something. I guess my only other complaint is that the gym is small but with a membership and enough gas money, you can visit their Poway gym which is betting in my opinion and not much further than Vertical Hold.

I've climbed here many times over the years. They recently made strides regarding the expansion and more actively resetting routes, but the bloom is off the rose now. These changes are lipstick on a pig.  FYI - I'm an experienced climber who has climbed many place. Here's the real deal with this joint:- staff could definitely be more attentive and professional.  I watched an employee free climb an entire top-rope route in flip flops while on the clock.  Great example you're setting for the customers (including kids) who were watching!!  I've also seen customers have to wait at the front desk while the employees go climb.- safety.  Can't believe no one has been hurt badly here.  Safety training since there are so many "tourist climbers." You can walk in, say you've climbed once ten years ago and they are like "cool. Next."  I've seen tons of dangerous belaying here - teens 2/3 up the wall and the belayer hasn't taken any rope.  The staff should definitely pay more attention to this sort of thing. - crowds!!!  It's small, and it's horrendous when they have parties of screaming kids (all the time!!). There's nothing more annoying or unsafe than a bunch of unsupervised kids running wild and doing idiotic stuff like standing directly below climbers who are bouldering or being belayed down.  The parents are even worse because they do the same things and should know better. - one of my biggest peeves is that the staff doesn't care if customers  throw their water bottles, backpacks, etc. on the ground near bottom of the wall you're climbing.  You land on that crap and you'll break your ankle.  No one cares. Not the staff, not the lazy customers, no one. - they have no computer system.  A year or so ago a staffer gave me crap b/c my annual membership had expired like 2 months ago.  I've never intentionally not paid, but isn't it the business's job to keep track of this sort of thing?  Duh! A computer costs $300 dollars today...- there are three positives. It's got a good location, it's cheaper than the other (superior) SD gyms, and the pebbles as footing are superior to the pads.  You can fall from higher and there is no bounce, unlike the terrible mats all the other gyms use.

First time rock climbing. Great gym with friendly employees and instructions are well taught and easy to follow. And they have snacks! They have a boulder climb room and it's great! Well I'm only a beginner... For now ^_^ definitely going again!

We just finished my son's 6th birthday party at Old Town's Solid Rock Gym. I couldn't be happier! The atmosphere was super chill and accepting. All of the boys and parents had such a good time. They all plan on bringing their kids back. Josh, our party attendant was great with the kids and was able to motivate them to try hard and climb higher. I hate structured parties with a bunch of frills. Having the birthday party there was perfect. Simple, accommodating, easy going, and AFFORDABLE! (Only 11$ per kid). I definitely recommend this for a kids birthday!

This place was our first experience at a rock climbing gym. I don't have anything to compare it to but we were very happy with our experience. The staff, Tommy and John, were awesome and very helpful with all of our questions. There were plenty of routes and the bouldering gave us tons of options to choose from. Another review said they had bad music but that person must have terrible taste because their tunes were perfect for the gym. Overall it was a great time and we are going back ASAP.
