One word: gross.(If you want more words, here you go: * The bathroom was covered in about a quarter inch of urine, which could be smelled all over the gym. Footprints led out of that to the climbs. Nasty. * One notable day, the manager and his buddies were playing dodgeball in the parking lot, leaving the gym unattended. Yes, they were hitting parked cars.*Employee smoke drifts in from the big bay door, stinking up the gym.*The lock on the ladies' room door was broken for an entire year. The gym solution was to put up a sign asking people to knock first.*A light fixture fell down in the locker room, nearly hitting my climb partner.*Employees walk around barefoot, feet dirty to the knee. Not barefoot between switching street shoes for climb shoes, but barefoot for entire shifts.*Another day, several hours after the last kid party, the upstairs area was still covered in food debris. The employees were chatting behind the desk. When we asked if we could just borrow a broom to clean it up ourselves so we could stretch, they said that they would get to it eventually.*There are no safety checks or safety protocols. I've seen belayers completely let go to take pictures of their climbers. I've seen people that 10' falls because their belayer doesn't know how to belay. This is not an employee problem. This is a complete lack of management and training. When I spoke with the owner, she blamed her apathetic employees instead of making changes. After five years with Solid Rock, I'm happy to have made the switch to Mesa Rim. Plus, all of the serious climbers I had missed were there, having given up on Solid Rock for the same reasons.)

I don't like the grigri on ropes. It also lacks intermediate routes. There are tons of easy routes, then it jumps from 5.6 to 5.9. And the 5.9 in this gym are definitely 5.10 in some. In general I just don't like the gym that much.

I signed up with yelp to rate this place. When I first walked in, I was impressed with the employees welcome but that is the only reason this gym gets two stars instead of one. The landing ground is filled with rocks. There are some crash pads but most of them are small and thin. The grades are ridiculous. There are no a, b, c, d's on the TR routes, it's either + or -, or just a solid grade is given. You can't belay with your own device, you must use their grigris and auto lock biners that are attached to noticeably fuzzy, hour-glass-shaped rope. They zip-tie their figure eight follow throughs on the belayers side for whatever reason (seems a bit lazy, sketchy and unprofessional). The employees sit behind the desk fooling around while unsupervised belaying children swing from their harnesses and scream in excitement.  The water fountain water pressure is so low you can barely drink from it, let alone fill your water bottle. There is so much needed to make that gym a better place. Start with getting different route setters and actually caring about safety in your climbing gym.

I attended a child's birthday party at the San Diego location recently and cannot say that it was a positive experience. The staff was just too cool for school, and made no attempt to hide the fact that they didn't want a bunch of lame-ass parents around crowding their gym. In many cases they were just down right rude, and not at all good with kids.I have been to a few child's parties at Vertical Hold in Miramar, and the experience was WAY better. The staff there were friendly and helpful. The climbing was more kid friendly. The harnesses and lines were better quality and they include climbing shoes (unlike Solid Rock, where the kids climb in street shoes). Vertical Hold also did not have a time limit on the climbing (unlike Solid Rock, where once the kids ate their birthday cake, they kicked us out).A disappointing experience to be sure. The attitude of the staff just ruined for me. If you are planning a party for young kids, skip this place.

Came here for my cousins birthday party. It was a lot of fun. They have a few different walls for all levels. It really works you out and if your afraid of heights this will push you to the limit. It's fun.

A friend of mine and I went for the first time five days ago on a whim!!!! We loved it, the staff is very friendly and attentive but not breathing down your neck, the routes were exhausting for us novices but we got a great workout. I worked muscles I didn't even know I had!!!! The price is very reasonable, the place open and airy with the bay open, lots of lighting!!!! My friend loved it so much that three days later she was telling me that she wanted to go back!!!! We will be back and I'm also considering getting a membership because I have caught the "Solid Rock climbing bug"!!!!!! My cousin now wants to go next time I do and this next weekend I am taking my nephews and brother!!! Thanks Solid Rock Gym, you have the nicest , coolest employees, who are not uptight!!!!! Good experience!!!

Great activity if you want to make a fun day of rock climbing in San Diego! It was my second time at Solid Rock and my boyfriends first. The first time I came here was in 7th grade on a field trip. Great for kids and teens!The girl behind the desk briefly explained what we need to do and checked up on us multiple times throughout our 2 hour visit to see how we were holding up. The ground is made of gravel, which was not great when I fell a couple times. Overall, a great experiene and I can't wait to go back!

In comparison to Mesa Rim and even Vertical Hold, I was astonished of how poor some of the routes were maintained. I love getting on a 10c and dyno'ing for a juggy knob only to have it shift out of placement 20' on TR (luckily on TR). My fav part is the bouldering section, it really does beat VH's because you have the ability to top out and don't have to mess with down climbing and landing on ankles. The slackline addition upstairs is pretty cool too, ghetto as *&!, but cool nontheless. They could do a better job labeling/marking the routes and holds in a more distinguished fashion, 2-5 are completely incomprehensible. Good to know before choosing the wrong rope idiot.

I took my Scout troop on our annual Climbing merit badge trip and, as usual, was not disappointed! The staff was FRIENDLY and HELPFUL, and JUSTIN did an awesome job with the kids! He was patient, friendly, and held their attention; not afraid to make sure that they paid attention (safety is paramount). He did a thorough job teaching them the skills they needed to climb. Outstanding job!

Found this place via yelp.  Took some of the criticism with a grain of salt, thinking the negative ones were a bit spoiled with their super nice gyms.  Unfortunately, I have to agree on their reviews.  I felt very nervous about taking my sister (a 1st time climber), especially since they didn't even ask if either of us had experience or knew how to belay.  The gym floor was gravel, which was not fall friendly.  No one checked up on us; the staff mainly stayed behind the front desk.  In addition to inadequate safety measures, I also felt the routes were inappropriately graded.  The top rope routes were ridiculously difficult and the bouldering was confusing, mismarked, and misleading at best.We had fun despite these concern, so, not a total waste.  Know better next time.

When I was a teenager, I used to scramble up and down the hills outside of my hometown in Arizona. The fact that I lived proved that Darwin's Natural Selection is true! So what do I do when I'm all grown up? I take up rock climbing. Darwin smiles.One of the places I frequent, is the Solid Rock Gym near Old Town (actually it's across I-5 from Mexican-American Restaurant heaven). This gym is not the prettiest, it's a bit dirty, it's a bit worn, but it's also a great place to get an awesome workout. Rock climbing will scare you right out of your socks (if you wear any), but it'll also make you feel ten feet tall - well maybe your arms will stretch out that far after climbing. Rock climbing gyms are dirty, they're supposed to be - a bit that is. Solid Rock was one of the first ever in San Diego and so you've got to understand why it looks the way it does.The Beta:- Reasonably priced: $12 to get in.- Cheap rentals: ($5) shoes and ($5) harness- I recommend renting their shoes for a better experience.- Locations: The original is close to downtown with a second in Poway- Climbing: Routes vary from beginner (white taped) to advanced- Parking: Not the best on a busy night (lots of nearby businesses).- Inside secret: They now have a new boulder area for members.- Group party area!Overall, I like it because it's close and it offers something for everyone.Check it out - makes for a great date place too.Climb on!

This place rocks! (Sorry, I couldn't resist!) Still, five stars for a wonderful birthday party experience. Our instructor, Tiffany, was great with all the kids and got them all up on the ropes quickly. She motivated them to push themselves and do their best - I was impressed!The party plan was an outstanding deal as we only paid for the kids who showed up and were not charged for the parents who wanted to give it a quick go. The party "room" is actually an upper deck, like a treehouse among the cliffs, where anyone who needed a break during our party time could sit down, have a drink, and cheer on their party-mates.We will definitely be back!

I'd give this rock gym a solid 3.5 - I'd go back again (and have) but there's room for improvement.I climbed in the Denver area for a good 5 years and got used to really nice gyms. I started going to SR while commuting to San Diego for work and got some of my co-workers learning to climb there. The newbies loved it, but had nothing to compare it to. From my standpoint:a. I found the routes to be pretty decent with good variety of skill level and pretty accurate ratings. b. I didn't mind the gravel floors, but I don't boulder.c. I was shocked they didn't require proof of belay knowledge or any test-out. S-C-A-R-Y! For the sake of the sport and everyone's safety, it's good to ensure folks know how to correctly belay and use the common verbal commands. d. I wouldn't trust their ropes for lead climbing. They looked well used and god knows how many big falls they've taken. All in all though, I think my expectations have been lowered now that I live in Orange County CA and haven't yet found a climbing gym I'd return to. I'd love to have this SR transported up to OC any day!

It's not fancy and doesn't have nice bathrooms/changing rooms, but the routes are fun, it's not too crowded, and you can get a beer in old town afterwards.  The routes are definitely more fun than those at Mesa Rim - although Mesa Rim is 'fancier' and definitely taller, the routes at Mesa Rim are pretty boring compared to Solid Rock.  And Solid Rock is WAY more affordable.

Five stars! Helpful and friendly staff. Excellent for a rock climbing noob like me to get her feet wet.  Whether you are a newbie like me or an old hand at rock climbing, this will be the right place for ya :)

Worst.  Rock gym.  Ever. I may be spoiled because I climb in the Bay Area where there are real rock gyms to choose from.  But even so, I know a crap place when I see one.  And San Diego has Vertical Hold a bit farther out, which is infinitely better than this fiasco of a gym.  Here's a non-exhaustive list of the things wrong with this lawsuit waiting to happen:1) No belay check.  I went with a novice climber.  We rented gear, and I asked if they wanted to show her how to tie in and belay, or if I could teach her and then have them test her.  They just asked me if I knew how to belay.  I said yes.  They said that was good enough and that I could just show her how to do it.  They never checked on us or tested her in any way.  Crazy.  2) The routes are set and graded by mentally handicapped chimps.  I'm not a great climber by any stretch, but I can do 5.10a's and b's pretty comfortably.  But at Solid Rock, I couldn't do a 5.7.  The routes made no sense whatsoever.  Some weren't graded at all.  You had to guess at what you were climbing, and when you'd look for a foothold, which would be the only way to make the next move, it wouldn't be there.  Terrible.3) Old ropes.  You don't have to tie in to top-rope -- you just clip the rope to your harness.  And the ropes look like they could use a serious upgrade.  4) Grimy, slippery holds.  'Nuff said. 5) No crash pads for bouldering.  After experiencing the magic of top-roping at solid rock, I thought I might try bouldering.  But there were no pads, and the floor is made up of pretty large gravel.  Yeah, that seems like it's going to feel good.  Sign me up.  I could go on.  But I won't.  Just don't bother with this place, I beg you.  Go to Vertical Hold, or keep driving north and go to Planet Granite in San Francisco.  You'll be a much happier climber.

My visit to Solid Rock Gym was a fun experience. The staff was friendly, informative and helpful, the equipment rental was in good working condition and the overall atmosphere and attitude of other climbers was ideal.  I give Solid Rock 3 stars simply because it's a bit pricey, the gym is smallish and the courses aren't all that challenging. An occasional visit is nice, but I don't think I would be interested in a membership here.

BRING YOUR OWN EQUIPMENT!  Their rental shoes smell disgusting.  Some of the worst smelling equipment I've ever encountered.  The guy at the front desk was extremely unfriendly and didn't seem to care about assisting us in the least.  Another thing that we didn't like was the rock filler on the ground.  Other gyms we go to have soft foam so if you fall while bouldering it's soft...here you need to drag a fall mat around.Lot of good routes and stuff.

I have been climbing at SR in Old Town for about 2 years. It's the only gym I've climbed at, but even then, there are things that I find very lacking:The ropes are mostly too short. If you're height impaired like me, the first person who clips in has to climb up the wall a little in order for the second person to clip in.Many of the ropes are frayed. Even though it's in a gym and it's safer than climbing outside, it still worries me a lot, it's a long fall.They advertise "free lesson", but when you ask about it, it's really just a belay lesson.The women's locker room is nonexistent. It'd be nice if there was an actual locker room with a shower instead of the little hallway in front of the bathroom. And the floors in the bathroom and in the "locker room" are not clean enough where I feel comfortable taking off my shoes in order to change.Maybe it's because I've been going there for a while, I haven't had many problems with service. But when I tried to renew my membership by downgrading from 6 months to monthly, the desk was entirely staffed by new hires and they had no idea what they're doing nor were they familiar with the policies.Nearly all of the lead climbing is in the cave with serious overhangs. It's pretty much impossible for someone to learn to lead climb in this place without having done a lot of it at other gyms or outdoors.The climbers there are pretty nice and friendly though, that's why I keep going there.

Ok, all you Bay area snobs, we get it.  This place isn't as good as the rockclimbing gyms in the Bay area.  Great.  That is super helpful.  Next time I want to go rock climbing at a gym I'll hop on a flight and join you at your uber excellent bay area rocksnob gym.  No this place isn't dangerous, and is not a law suit waiting to happen.  It's owned by two attorneys, who, believe it or not, know more about liability then you do!  I personally love solid rock.  Yeah, some of the criticisms are fair.  They use the cheater belay devices.  No one can free fall and get hurt that way, which is good, but the climbers aren't practicing tying in and belaying, which is bad.  The top roping could be higher, the workout area could be nicer, and they could have some showers...The staff is friendly.  The routes are good, with a wide variety of difficulty, ranging from 5.7-5.12+.  The bouldering area has tons of good problems.  The rates are reasonable.  I started climbing here, and love it.  I am sure there are better indoor gyms, but this is great place to learn, and improve your skill.  I go 5x per week.  It's the only gym within ten minutes of downtown, hillcrest, mission valley, pt. loma/ocean beach, missin beach, pac beach, etc.  It's right off the 5 which makes getting there easy from all over.  So unless you want to drive inland, or fly to the bay area, I recommend it.DISCLAIMER: This review is a natural product. The minor inconsistencies in spelling and grammar only enhance its distinct character and are in no way to be considered flaws or defects.

I enjoyed Solid Rock.  Granted, Yelp steered me wrong by having the wrong address at 2704 Hancock instead of the correct one at 2074 Hancock.  It's a funny street, divided by a freeway, a highway, and railroad tracks.  I was totally lost.  Boo.But that's not solid rock's fault.Let the record state that I don't like doing things that make me feel stupid or are outside of my comfort zone.  Rock climbing falls into that category.  However, it was a friend's bachelor party plan and I'm the best man, so off we go to climb some rocks.Solid Rock is a cheery, well-ventilated, well-lit indoor rock climbing gym.  It does get crowded a bit fast, but the staff are cheerful and helpful from my experience and I greatly enjoyed my stay.  My favourite part?  The very bizarre and differently shaped hand and foot holds on the rock walls.  Some look like neo-Art Deco pieces; others look like overblown skateboard wheels.  Overall, they're pretty damn cool.  I enjoyed it, and while it hasn't made a rock climber out of me, it seems like a good place to let off some steam, or take the kids for a birthday party (there were two when I was there, plus a boy scout jamboree).

SRG took my rock climbing virginity, It was a wonderful and scary experience. We told the girl that it was our first experience and she took us and two other girls who've never climbed either to a wall and briefly explained the basics: how to hold, how to lock etc...all in about 5 minutes (which at the time seemed enough for me until I went to vertical hold and was impressed at how much time they spent teaching you the proper ways of things). I climbed up the wall and felt such joy when I got to the top, that is until I looked down and imagined myself plummeting to my death. 'Okay now lean back and let go of the wall' the staff yelled up at me. 'Are you crazy woman!' I yelled back down at her. I was prepared to climb up, but wasn't prepared for what I had to do when I had reached the top. The trainer didn't check to make sure that the rope was taut, so when I finally let go of the wall I dropped a bit. Scary stuff when it's your first time. I don't always understand the routes. I imagine someone around 6ft is the one that's setting them, because the distance between the rocks are near impossible for someone of my height to reach. The rocks are not always screwed in properly, so sometimes when you step on a rock it'll shift causing you to loose your footing. I guess they're trying to give you that real life feel to climbing, getting you used to rocks slipping under you. The place is small but the staff are really friendly and so are the patrons. Everyone is always willing to give you some pointers as long as you ask.

Good times!  Been to this location only once, and it was full of more adults than the Poway Solid Rock gym -- everyone is very laid back.  Lots of fun racing to the top and watching the pro's climb upside down and swing around boulders by their fingertips!

Oh, they're expanding this location! I can't wait!!  They bought some space next door and will inc the lockerroom and add in more walls. Yeah!!  Should be coming in the next couple months.I think it's ironic, even though it seems so many yelpers don't like this place, it's almost always packed when I come (and as a memeber, I come 1-2 times a week).  So they must be doing something right. *wink*

I love this place and the staff that works there. Also the art work on the wall is amazing ;). Karen is the best! So happy she is back. I wish they had like one treadmill or elliptical. Something for cardio.

Ah Old Town, the smallest and busiest of the 3 remaining SRG gym's. They just got a new boulder for members. This place can be discouraging because of the crowds. I'd suggest you bring a partner and an ipod. The lead cave is the steepest of all 3 and their routes get changed the most because it sees 3-4 times more traffic than the other 2 gym's combined. I used to be a routesetter for all their gym's and loved the variety of working in a fast paced gym versus a more relaxed more family oriented one. It's the oldest gym in San Diego with steel reinforced wood frame (except for the new boulder). It will have the most variety because they set more hard routes there. San Marcos and Poway do college night. 1 hour of steady consistent climbing burns more calories than none stop running for an hour or lifting weights or swimming (up to 1000 calories)
Great time, great value!  Try it, you'll love the workout!

This review is for Climbing Merit badge experience done on the  weekend of 8/11/2012Two session course and we had 12 scouts participating. Ben and Anthony were our instructors and they were great with the scouts.They class portion had great overview of climbing and plenty of visual aids. They both were very encouraging with all the kids, getting them to push a little harder above what each kid thought was their ability level. Great reviews from the scouts, especially day 2 when Anthony let them try the slackline. Overall a great experience I would recommend it to other groups who want intro to climbing.Over all 4.5 stars. Only reason why it wasn't 5 is there was a lot of confusion on the booking and cost. I called in a few times and got different information on how much it was going to cost,  but it all worked out. Bottom line to earn merit badge cost is $30 per person minimum of 8. Minimum 1 week advance notice and non refundable $100 deposit to secure the reservation, but is applied towards the cost. No need to rent shoes for beginners it doesn't make a difference.

Let me put out a disclaimer before reading beyond this as to why I rated this place as one-star:I guess it's a good and fun place for people who don't normally climb and want to do something new, but as a climber, this place made me really angry and upset.As a climber I like to find new gyms and experience different climb setters. I come from Threshhold Gym in Riverside, check it out if you're in the area.Back to Solid Rock- I was visiting my boyfriend's cousin out there and we had some time to kill, so we brought his cousin for her first time climbing. We'd never been there before but we assumed it would be cool to try out a new gym. She liked it for her first time, but we totally hated it.The gym passes are so damn expensive for what you get! Okay, if you are new to climbing then sure, knock yourself out- but I didn't get ANYTHING I paid for. It was $16 on the weekend for a freakin' adult pass. So what does that get me? Access to crappy EVERYTHING. Why?1) Their holds are never cleaned. Judging by the look/feel of it, every hold was greasy and left uncleaned from probably MONTHS.2) The workers ALLOW people to climb with normal shoes on. HELLO, that is what makes all of the holds so greasy! You should be climbing with shoes that have rubber soles specifically meant for climbing, or you will be greasing up the holds and people like me won't have fun slipping off anything and everything!3) Their route (and bouldering) ratings are COMPLETELY OFF. I did a 5.9 route that probably would have been a 5.10 outdoors with a 5.11 crux. I checked their website, and they even have a section that says "Interested in route setting?" so really, like ANYONE can come in and set up a route? No wonder why their ratings are so inconsistent! Also, I warmed up on this supposed-to-be V0 in the adult section (yes, the bouldering is in a separate room that is 18+ years old only... but I still saw children in there), and that in my eyes was a V3. What kind of V0 really makes your feet cut in the gnarliest way so that you can fly backwards and eat a mouth full of...4) ...PEBBLES. What the hell, really... typically all climbing gym floors should be padded! but PEBBLES!? They filled the entire gym with pebbles (or may I say little rocks, because these were NOT Cocoa-Pebbles-sized pebbles, they were pretty huge). In addition, They had a limited about of crashpads that were all disproportionate and ripped up because they were handmade and stuffed with cheap foam. Accidents happen, and sometimes people don't land ALL on the crashpad... in fact, my boyfriend landed one foot on the pad and one foot on the pebbles and his ankle started hurting, even with me spotting him!5) This gym does not teach safety or how to do things properly. Yes, for convenience on all the ropes they have attached a gri-gri and have tied it in so that you cannot take it off and put it back on improperly... but I still see people clipping themselves in in some kind of stupid fashion that makes it five times harder to bring someone down. 6) Their gear is all worn out. Just like the uncleaned holds, their gri-gris are extremely worn out, as well as their ropes. Try to replace some of this stuff every once in a while! With the money they are charging for day passes and memberships, it's unacceptable to have this low-grade stuff in this gym.The only thing I looked forward to was that they had a crack climb section, however the inside of the crack was completely smooth from too much chalk and usage, and the crack was way too big to do a single handjam, so I kept slipping.If I had to rate this gym, I'd give it a big fat F. This place is completely unacceptable for experienced climbers and probably even dangerous for people who are inexperienced! Judging from the crowd, this place was filled with a lot of little kids running around with tennis shoes on, so I assume maybe this gym caters to little kids and people who are inexperienced. Even still, the upkeep is unacceptable- this gym is expensive and unkempt. If i had the option to give it NO STARS and even take the ones they earned away! believe me, I would. If I was in the area and had to satiate my craving for climbing, I'd rather bring a hammer and chisel off a random boulder in the area rather than go to this gym.

Great place to climb, very laid back atmosphere, lots of friendly regulars.  If your looking to waited on or catered to this might not be the gym for you.  But if your looking for a fun time climbing at a reasonable price, come on down and climb.  Love that there is a small weights gym upstairs.  There is a section for slack lining, a nice sized lead climbing cave, and a big old bouldering room which is pretty awesome.

We just had our sons birthday there, it turned out awesome! Luis was great with the kids and made sure everyone had safety instructions. We all had a blast. Loved that you could see the whole gym from the party room.

If you're looking for a decent place to work out, without having to go to a boring gym, then you are looking in the right place!As far as I know, Solid Rock is really the only option in San Diego for indoor rock climbing. But because it's the only option, don't think they skimp on good tracks and lots of variety in wall selection, because they don't. There are lots of different walls and tracks from beginner to advanced. It's also a great idea for a kids party (they do them A LOT). So go and try it out!

The location is a bit hard to get to, if you're not coming off of The 5 South. The gym is pretty small and it is always full of kids. There is no real technical knowledge of climbing, the climber clips in to an auto-locking clip and the belayer has a grigri belay device, which takes out any sort of thinking, all you have to do is keep the slack out.Not really recommended for more challenging climbs, but it does have 'white' trails on every top line, which allow for an easy ascent to boost confidence and warm-up.The last time I was here we only got in 1.5 hrs of climbing before kids took over every top rope.

Poorest quality gym I have ever seen on every Level. We were visiting from Seattle for the weekend and stopped in to climb. As everyone says, there are young kids everywhere belaying each other and climbing on the walls. SO SO SO unsafe. The routes are not rated wrong, the routes as many have stated are not even routes. I have climbed for 15 years all over, lead 11's and could not get up 5.9's because the the holds are randomly placed, totally polished and the routes make no sense.  Even worse are the ropes that are unbelievably HORRIBLE!! You have to manually feed them through the sticky grigri's. We watched kids doing this and they had to REMOVE THEIR BRAKE  hand to push/and or pull the rope through and could never have caught the climber if the rope had suddenly started feeding. I am going to post a picture showing the rope... one end looks like a thread while the other end is fat and won't feed. We did not climb on one rope that had the core intact.It is unreal to me that they can run a gym like this and actually have members that accept any of this.Obviously the owner is not a climber and has no interest in safety or quality of his gym. I do hope he is making a good income from his business because clearly that is all that matters to him.The girls working there said everyone has the same complaints and the owner won't make changes. In addition there is a  suggestion box there asking people to write down their complaints instead of yelping. That kind of says it all for me!I
Ben was awesome today with our family that was visiting from out of state. This is our second time to the gym and each time we received great customer service. We would highly recommend.

Scouter's Beware.  Their website advertises the following (copied and pasted)"Scouts will learn how to use our climbing equipment, learn climbing commands and the necessity of communication while climbing. The Scouts will also get to boulder and top rope.This program is taught in a single two-hour session. Upon completion, the participants will receive their very own embroidered INDOOR ROCK CLIMBING PATCH.COST: $15 per scout + nontransferable $50 deposit at the time of the reservation. (minimum 6 participants) "We made phone reservations and told them we were bringing a group of about 20-30 scouts.   They made no mention of the little to no parking.  It's mostly street parking.   When we got there, the guy behind the counter was rude and unpleasant.   The trainer was nice, but all he did was demonstrate how to use the ropes.   Nothing like what their website lead me to believe.   The walls were a little too difficult for our younger boys.  Some of the rocks were loose and the walls were very dirty.   There was little padding on the floor and relatively little to no supervision from the staff.   At the end, we were hoping that the boys would be presented with their patches, instead, we had to ask for the patches and when we did, they tried to charge us $3 a piece.   When we explained that their website made no mention of an extra charge nor did they ever mention it to us when we made the reservations, the guy actually argued with us, right in front of the kids and families.   Very unprofessional.  Why would we book a "SCOUT PACKAGE" that is more expensive then the regular price and assume that there would be an EXTRA charge for the patches?   He finally gave us the patches, but he was obviously not happy about it.   We'll be looking for another place to take our Pack to next year.

Love this place! It might not be the fanciest, but there's a great vibe, the staff are friendly and laid-back, the prices are good, and I almost always have an awesome time here. The clients vary from beginners to experts (I'm more towards the beginner side myself), but I never get that "I'm SO much better than you, watch how awesome I am!" vibe that I've gotten at other gyms.Other reviewers have mentioned the kids, and I do agree that they can be annoying at times (they host birthday parties and Girl Scout training there). The individual climbers who come with their own kids are usually fine, but the giant groups can be a bit much! I've found that avoiding peak hours (like Saturday afternoons) works best if you can't stand the kids (you can always ask the staff what times are more crowded).My boyfriend and I purchased a 6 month membership and it has been well worth the money so far! Officially, they are supposed to charge members for equipment, but they actually don't, so we get to climb for free whenever we want, plus get guest passes!As for those who have complained about the lack of instruction, well, maybe you should actually pay for an instruction session?

I cannot believe how unsafe the gym is! They don't bother testing people's belay skills! I've seen people clipped in wrong, people leaving several feet of slack in their climber's line and people soloing walls and taking breaks by clipping their harness to a quickdraw! The worst had to be when a school group of about 60 12 year olds came in. Two of the boys clipped in to a rope near us and then the one with the grigri started climbing the wall while his friend just pulled on the rope! He was probably 25 feet up before we noticed. Luckily there was 4 of us so 2 held the rope and 2 spotted him while he climbed back down. The worst part is when I finally found an instructor and told her, she seemed more annoyed with me for making it a big deal than concerned for the boy's safety. I'd say the only reason no one has died is because the walls are only 30 feet. I don't care if you use grigris and auto-locking carabiners, you should be making sure people know what they're doing!
Legit.  The guy knew I had never been rock climbing before, so he was extra helpful.  He also gave me gear and shoes for free.  Awesome.

"Rock climbers do it against the wall."    Solid Rock is best if you just want to show up and get climbing. They'll take a few minutes to show you what you need to do for top roping, but you aren't tying any knots or doing anything fancy. Depending on your desire, this could be a good or a bad thing. Either way, it's great fun and a great work out. The staff is pretty hands-off which makes me feel comfortable, as they're not breathing down your neck and/or judging you, and if you specifically ask them for help they're pretty responsive.Their top-roping routes starts have an easy way up (the Girl Scout route), then increase in difficulty to 5.7 and above. The bouldering section (without ropes & harness)  is a lot of fun, with challenging traverse and sit-start sections. There's something for everyone here, including an awesome lead-climbing section which you have to get clearance to try. If you are going to do top-roping, bring a friend to belay you while you climb and vice versa.The only thing I must point out is there are quite a few greasy. loose, or broken holds, and a few disabled or weathered ropes. And for about $18 a visit or $75 a month, you'd hope for slightly more pristine conditions. Definitely go for a day, you just might like doing it against the wall!
The place is really cool for kids. They have some easy and some challenging courses and walls, but all in all it is fun.

I came here with a few buddies who have a membership and had a free pass.  staff was cool, came in, signed the waiver, got some shoes, and was on my way.  Spent most of our time in the bouldering area so cant comment on the other areas.  There was one or two birthday parties going on and a bunch of kids who appeared to be having a good time.  The bouldering area was nice, not too crowded, challenging walls, and cool people.  Overall a great first time experience.

First timer  - that's my disclaimer.  I quite liked this place based on my rock climbing gym naïveté and innocence. It's a good date spot --men who know what they are doing *hint *hint. I had a lot of fun.  It was laid back. I didn't feel like I needed a degree to be the novice that I am, although, I put safety first and made sure to understand the physics behind belaying etc... as I didn't want to drop anyone off the side of a colorful artificial rock mountain.

My home away from home. I don't need to try any other climbing gyms, let alone even go out to the other Solid Rock's. I love this place, I love the staff, I love the climbing. I never really use the upstairs gym part but it has everything you need, a campus board, rings, training board with all the holds and weights. The bouldering room is basically the only part I use since I don't have any friends or climbing partners to come belay me on the top ropes. I also love the traverse boulder in the middle of the main room. Great for endurance and always has some sweet problems on it. I'm glad to be a member here.
I've been here once and I did the boulder today. It was fun and a great workout.  Bruce the front desk was very helpful and friendly.I will definitely go back again.

We had a great experience at Solid Rock for my daughter's birthday.  Justin was our climbing guide and did a phenomenal job.  He was fun with the kids and made my husband and I laugh.  He was helpful and gave the kids clear directions and then cheered them on as they climbed.  It was great.  We would definitely go back.  My only suggestion for the gym is that they allow you to leave a tip when using a credit card.  We ended up going to get cash and coming back.  Justin was worth every penny.  Thanks for a great experience!
This place totally rocks!  Haha!  But seriously, knowledgeable and attentive staff, easy first time use safety equipment, a great variety of climbs, and it's all a great deal!

Solid rock is a great climbing gym. The routes are interesting and the general culture is welcoming. The staff are friendly and knowledgeable, Tommy, in particular, is helpful, cool, and gives good beta.

Front desk folks very nice, and a good location relative to downtown, but shocked with the lax safety of this place compared to other outfits like Sport Rock in DC.  Flooring is all river rock, no wall to wall padding.  Nary a helmet in sight.  Hard concrete curbing in close proximity to many of the climbs.  How the hell did this place ever qualify for liability insurance?

Many of the complaints I've seen on this page really are frivolous or non existent. I find it funny that the lowest ratings here are from people out of the area. Gyms in San Fransisco or LA are better but also cost  a lot more for a monthly membership and a day pass. Ropes and holdings are in good conditionRoutes are good for beginners or for Advanced climbersThere are routes for clipping in as you go if you're advanced or easy lock in top ropesSeveral Bouldering areas, Arches and a CaveRoutes are consistently changingThe staff is friendly and will help you if you're not experiencedThere are plenty of times when the gym's not over crowdedAlso there are are groups that meet up if you need a belay partnerThe price is also less than other gyms for a day pass and membershipThere are 3 different locations in San Diego county so if you get tired of one location or want to try some different walls you have 2 other locations to  choose from for the same price.

Awesome gym! The first time my friend and I went the staff was super friendly and helpful. We ended up signing up for a membership that day. I havent been to any other gyms in the SD area but I dont think I need to, SRG has it all!

I have nothing but good things to say about this place. Took a group of nine students here this past weekend and they all had a great time. Our instructor, Ben, did an absolutely amazing job. I can't say enough great things about him and his patience with our group. He not only helped us but he also had our names memorized by the end of the first hour. That is great customer service. We will be coming back for another event for sure!

this place is pretty cool to start climbing or to do some bouldering. Although the majority of the bouldering area is only available if you are older than 18. All of the top rope climbs are fun but the height of the walls aren't that impressive. They have a cave where people can lead climb with some very challenging routes. They require you to use their ropes. Sometime they host parties so the place can get a crowded easily. Staff seems nice and helpful every time i have been there. Good place to start if you are new to climbing. The routes are challenging and still offer a good workout.

It may not have the biggest walls in San Diego but it has a great community and great setters. I've met a ton of awesome people here and have advanced my climbing many grades since joining. It can get a little crowded at times when they host birthday parties but there is an excellent 18 and over bouldering room that stays pretty open. They change their routes pretty frequently, about once every two months or so as far as I can tell.

My boyfriend and I went with some friends and had a great time! We brought our own gear but they have harnesses and shoes for rent too- were both a little rusty and they were happy to give us a little refresher. Staff was helpful and nice and the climbers were really friendly too. A great way to spend a rainy night, or any night for that matter. Check it out!

terrible. okay, so admittedly i have been spoiled by the sf bay area's gyms, but this was the saddest rock climbing gym i've ever been to. i mean there was just so much wrong about this gym. my roommate's bf, a serious rock climber and route setter, warned me not to go. i went anyhow, and wish i had paid attention to his advice.here is what was just wrongness all over:1. they don't belay check. okay so admittedly, they use caribiners on the figure-8 end and a gri-gri, but seriously, people can get really messed up and hurt on poor belaying. my belay check consisted of the girl asking "do you know how to belay? cause if you do, that's your belay check." uhhh. being flippant = someone getting hurt.2. the routes. ridiculous. some started at my head. and when you got up to the 1st or 2nd holds, they didn't make sense. unless you could fly, there was no way to get to the next holds. and they were poorly marked. 5.10. a 5.10 what? a, b, c or d? stickers were peeled off so there was no way of telling the difficulty of some routes. others weren't even marked.3. the holds. grimy, dirty, and totally not powerwashed. gross.4. the belay ropes. some of them were so short you had to step up onto the holds in order to rope in and have your belayer rope in. other ropes has this weird thing where excess rope was tied into a bundle, and taped over with masking tape into this potato-shaped thingy. sort of interferes with the gri-gri, if you ask me. and they were crazy frayed, which made taking up the slack really hard. like abnormally hard.i was so disappointed. so not coming back. vertical hold is much better.

I learned to climb here at Solid Rock in Old Town. So I am a bit biased, but some of these complaints are just completely wrong. The staff are rude and uncaring? TOTALLY not true, they will come out there and help you with ANYTHING, belaying, fixing a broken/loose hold, or missing tape, they will even come out and help with bouldering problems sometimes. And so what if they play around behind the counter? It isn't as if they are leaving people without help. I would much prefer fun employees with personality over staunch and stuffy ones.Ok yes, at first the gravel does not seem like a good idea, but trying falling on it! I have fallen flat on my back many a time and it is not what you would think. Also, I know climbers there, including myself, who would rather fall on the gravel than a pad. It displaces the impact very nicely. At Mesa Rim, letting go feet first onto those flat mats scares the crap out of me, I feel like I could break my ankle. I would rather fall on rocks any day.Now when people say the routes are poorly set, yes, there is some validity to that. Many of them are harder than the routes in most gyms, despite the fact that they have low ratings. But, this makes it much more realistic to outdoor climbing! So when that guy from the bay area complains that on a 5.7 he only has a foothold to step up on for the next move, he is actually clmbing much more realistically than he would if he simply had to reach up to a nice jug! All over the gym, there are white routes that are SUPER easy, so quit your griping!I am not much of a top roper, I am mainly a boulderer, but when I read these complaints about the belay devices, it blows my mind! TOO EASY TO USE?!?! What the hell is wrong with having a belay device that a beginner could use right off the bat? It works for them, and it works for all those experienced top ropers. If you want the real experience, just go to the lead climb cave! There you get all of the fun of the real thing in a safe place.The one complaint I would ever have, is the kids. If you can, try try try your best to avoid the middle of the day on weekends or during the summer. But they have to make money somehow right? Just go in the evening/night! The other climbers are so friendly, I guarantee that if you go alone, you'll leave with at least 2 new climbing buddies. All-in-all, yea it's a bit dirty. Yea some of the routes are harder than they are rated. And yea there are kids that run rampant during the day. But for me, there is no other choice for a sure fire good climb. I know that when I go, I can spend hours and hours just trying a few problems until I get them down perfectly. Plus, the harder climbs, make me a better climber when I go other places. The charm of this place, trumps everything else I've ever been to.

I've been to gyms where they did not want you to use chalk because it was too messy, where to climb lead you had to study two pages of does and don't, where you were expected to know the precise tie in method desired, and lectured like a child if you didn't guess correctly.   I've climbed at Solid Rock gym on a regular basis for many years now, and I can tell you it is not like that.  If you are a climber and going there just once, your experience will vary depending on your attitude, as these other reviews will attest. This review will hopefully give you a heads up so that your visit may be more enjoyable.     The first thing you do when you enter this or any climbing gym is SIGN YOUR LIFE AWAY. This should ring a bell.  It's DANGEROUS PEOPLE,but If you expect someone to hold your hand and baby you, forget it and go ride a bike.    Beginners:  This gym uses fixed carabineers and grigris on the top ropes.  This means that less practice is required to belay safely and less time is spent tying in,so you get to climb more.  Pay attention when the staff explains how to use the system.  If you don't get it, ask again. They will help you. There are lots of climbs for beginners.     intermediate climbers: The top rope climbs rate from 5-8 to 5-12.  The ratings can vary widely so expect to get spanked on some routes that are rated at  what you think your level is.  They change the routes faster than I can get used to them, and I think rating stuff is dumb anyway.  I do set routes there from time to time and my feeling is that, if you are always looking at ratings as an indicator, then it is much better for me to sand bag the numbers so that you don't go outside and get yourself killed on something you thought you should be able to climb.  If you get my 5-10b then you are pretty much in there for 5-10b's.     Experts:  5-13 and up.  Well, you are mostly out of luck.  You would probably like the lead cave and could get a long workout in but there simply aren't enough of you to justify setting routes in that range.   Bouldering:  They have a great new top out boulder, and kids are not allowed. It really is way cool,but it scares me.   The only complaint I've heard is that the problems are not hard enough, but I hear a lot of grunting and yelling when I pass by.  I really don't want to know what is going on in there.  Oh! They have a slack line and a peg board.  How about that?      Lead climbing:  I think this is the best lead "cave" I've ever climbed in.  It is really overhung and intimidates most climbers, but it is a total kick.  The routes run from 5-9 to 5-13+ (only one)  with most in the 10+ to 11+ range. You have to get certified to climb lead.  You can tie in with a dbl. figure eight or a dbl. boline, with backup.  You have to understand back clipping and z clipping;that is know not to do it.  This gym provides rope and the atc. Once you have tested on a climb and passed,  they leave you alone, something I like.  To enjoy the cave you are going to have to be a very solid 5-10 climber.  You have to give the desk something of value to check out the ropes.  I keep a kid in the back of my truck for just such occasions, but keys or I.D. will work they tell me.     If you are just beginning to lead, there is another flat section in the gym where you can check out a rope and  practice lead with a top rope belay.    If you hate kids, or crowds then check ahead. They do have parties up over the boulder.  Sometimes they will give you treats if you perform well in the lead cave, a plus.    They do not have showers.  Do you really want to step into a public shower?  You have no idea what just went on in that space you are stepping into.  They  have lockers in the new boulder area, really nice, carpet, even a table with magazines and stuff.  Alas they are not coed.  No juice bar either.     I admit that gravel in the top rope areas is not really necessary, and mats would be cleaner, but that isn't the way the gym was made years ago.  However, I can personally tell you that if one of your bozo friends isn't paying attention and drops you twenty feet in the lead cave, you are going to kiss that gravel for breaking your fall, twice.    I like the staff, friendly,enthusiastic, but not hovering.  I like the routes, always a challenge whatever the rating.  I especially like the people I meet there, always nice, willing to give advice or a belay, and they let this old guy hang with them, sort of.  I take all the other little picky complaints, too dusty, hate gravel, lose holds,fat ropes,kids, no Beethoven's ninth on the c.d. with a grain of salt, because you won't find a nicer bunch of gym rats anywhere.

It's reasonably priced, but a bit smaller than some of the other climbing gyms in San Diego. Also, if you're there on the weekend, there's a 50/50 chance of overlapping with a kid's birthday party group, which can be annoying.

great gym lot of fun great for family's/ beginners to pro's the lead cave is awesome and there are great routes and the staff are super friendly and helpful i recommend the gym to any body how is thinking of going

Solid Rock Gym is a great place to learn how to climb and improve your skills.  Are there better places?  Yes, but not this close to my house.  The rates are reasonable and the routes are fun and they are continually changing them.  Just go and have fun, but avoid the weekends unless you go late because of all the kids parties.
